Comment: Which reminds me, willow...the book may well "misrepresent" reality. 

All autobiographies do, to some extent.  Because they are written by people who were IN the history they write about, or, in some instances, WERE the history they write about. Memories are short and they are selective.  Some selectivity is unconscious (that's bad) some is deliberate (that's worse.) Sometimes, nobody knows for sure. 

I like what Winston Churchill said about his multi-volume History of WW II: "This is not history; this is my case."

So, given all that, Ms. Wente's column is extremely valid.

Comment: So how big of a sales tax would be required?  Juneau has a 5% sales tax and brings in $43 million spread across about 30,000 residents.  Expand that to the entire state and that brings in about $1 billion.  But it has a few problems:
1.  Juneau gets a million cruise tourists a year, so sales tax revenue is likely higher there than it would be elsewhere.  In reality the state sales tax would need to be 6% or more.
2.  Many out-of-state owned businesses skip town without remitting their taxes.  Difficult to enforce when the business is operating in the Virgin Islands or whatever winter cruise port.  It's a perennial problem there.
3.  A state sales tax would be piled on top of existing municipal sales taxes in the communities that have them (i.e. Juneau would have a 10% sales tax).  So they would have to switch to higher property taxes which the sales tax supporters would probably consider even less fair.

If you just gotta have a sales tax, make it a big one only in the summer season.

Comment: Gold does not "combine" with mercury.  Gold adheres to mercury.  Both remain unchanged in this process.  During the multiple American gold rushes the larger pieces of placer gold were easy to pick out of the gravel in which they were found.  The miners would use a sheet of copper, cleanse it with sulfuric acid, and coat it with mercury.  The gravel containing the finer bits of gold was then washed over the mercury coated copper plate and the gold stuck to it.  The mercury-coated gold was scraped off the plate and this was heated to vaporize the mercury.  Native gold is usually about 18-20 karat.  To purify the gold it was mixed with borax and heated to high temperature.  The gold melted, the impurities combined with the borax, everything cooled down, the slag was chipped away and Voila!  24 carat pure gold.

Now in April it is at 1.1%, lower than any of them! Oddly, one of the reasons for that is its greatest strength: it is the only core measure that excludes mortgage interest cost. Its annual inflation rate was -1.5% in April 2016 but in April 2017 it finally rose to 0.0%. Well, the lives that we NOW lead EVERYWHERE in Alaska, including the villages, would be impossible. One of the more cherished Alaskan myths is that folks in the villages - Native or otherwise - live a "subsistence lifestyle". Sure, harvesting local fish, wildlife, and plants is a much larger component of the economy in villages than in urban/suburban Alaska. But no one lives a "subsistence lifestyle", i.e., living entirely, or nearly so, from gathering resources off the land. All of us are quite reliant on the products of the cash economy. All. Think otherwise? Reflect on the chorus for "disaster" relief when the sole fish buyer left Quinhagak. And watch closely as our oil-bubble economy winds down.

There may be a few remarkable souls in the Amazon or Borneo living a subsistence life. Not us.

Sprinklers in the common area will probably slow the fire down, but will it be enough to prevent it from spreading to other units?  By the time the fire reaches the common area, it might be too intense to be doused by the common area sprinklers.  On the other hand, if individual units have their own sprinkler system, it's more likely the fire will be doused or slowed down before it can intensify enough to spread to the common area.  As far as smoke goes, when there's fire, there's smoke, so regardless of where the sprinklers are located, smoke is inevitable.  The common area is an issue but not the "BIG" issue.  It's best to have sprinklers in the units and the common areas.

Whether their cause was worthy or not is irrelevant, IMO.  There's ample opportunities for NFL stars to leverage their fame and their built-in media coverage to protest a cause if they want, WITHOUT dissing the national anthem and all that it stands for.  He made a terrible choice, and he's paying the price for it.  And rightfully so, IMO.

Comment: Earnings Reserve not the panacea the legislature thinks!

Permanent Fund Principle is a calculated number and only grows:  Contributions + Inflation Proofing.

Permanent Fund Principle does NOT fluctuate with market changes.  Market value changes of the fund are totally absorbed by the Earnings Reserve and it can swing $5 billion in a month or two.

As an example, say the market value at the time of the withdrawal is calculated is $52 b and the Principle is $45 b.  A draw of 5.25% would be $2.73 b, leaving a market value of $49.27 b.  Now imagine a market decline like we just had in January to February 2016 of 10%.

The result?  No more Earnings Reserve.
$49.27 b * 10%  = $4.927 b
$49.27 b - $4.927 b =$44.34 b

$44.34 b market value - $45 billionb Principle = NO Earnings Reserve.

The Senate is playing with fire folks, call your Senator and tell them to stay the hell away from the Permanent Fund and PFD.  Cut tax credits to oil and gas, eliminate natural gas pipeline spending, use CBR.
